author: Special Correspondent
text:
Final year postgraduate students of English of Fatima College here accomplished an academic social responsibility on Monday with the release of ‘River Once,’ a documentary on the legendary Kiruthumal river, which is as ancient as the Vaigai.

The 11-minute documentary, made in association with the Centre for Development Communication of Dhan Foundation, traces the origin of the river, records expert views on its history and shifts focus to its present state of being a stinking drain. The river, which once went around the city as a ‘garland,’ ran for 74 km in Madurai, Sivaganga, Virudhunagar and Ramanathapuram districts and had a basin area of 1251 square km.

G. Periasamy, Deputy Hydro Geologist, Tamil Nadu Water Supply and Drainage Board, who released the documentary, said that he would submit a project for recharging and renovation of the Kiruthumal for funding by the State Finance Commission. S. Venkataraman, a resident of Thuvariman, suggested that a link be provided for the Kiruthumal near Achchampaththu village from the Nilayur channel to ensure flow and thereby revive the river.

Rev. Sr. K. Fatima Mary, Principal, said that the documentary should prick the conscience of people.

S. Geetha, Head, Research Department of English, described the work as a “novel, original and informative project.”

P. Krishnamurthy, Programme Leader, Dhan Foundation, explained how the project shaped up.
title: An ode to a river of yore
